Dear Ms. Lessnau:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
09/27/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
Four of eighteen new employee records reviewed did not
contain documentation of three references for the respective
employees, documented as a volunteer and interns.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's
case record:
(b) A photograph taken within the previous 12 months.
One of six open resident records reviewed showed the child’s
photo was four days after the resident ‘s 6/13/19 admission.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's
case record:
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as
required in R 400.4132.
Three of six open resident records reviewed did not show
documentation the grievance policy was provided to the referral
source.
4

R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
Four of four closed resident records reviewed did not show
documentation of the name and title of the person the resident
was discharged to.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
None.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
None.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.4113(b) Employee records.
 The agency was apprised a true copy of verification of education is required.
Denoting that the original was seen on a copy of the document does not
substitute for what is required by the rule.
R400.4166(1) (c) & (e) Discharge plan.
 The agency was apprised it shall consistently document the resident’s needs
still to be met, indicating any follow up needs for the resident.
 The agency was apprised its discharge plan shall clearly show a statement
that the discharge plan recommendation, including medical and dental follow-
up that is needed, have been reviewed with the resident, parent, and
responsible case manager.
5

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.4166(1)(f) Discharge plan.
 The agency was advised revision of its form title “Change of Placement” or
another form to a discharge summary form that contains a line to input the
name, and title of the person the resident was discharged, along with a space
for that person to sign and date, may aid it in showing clearer and consistent
compliance to the rule.
Contract: RFCAN 2.10.1(e)Planned Discharge-Contact
 The agency was advised adding the name of the child’s caregiver on its
aftercare contact sheet, along with including the social worker’s
name/signature on the date of the contact, (as opposed to initials), may aid in
showing clearer documentation of this contract requirement.
 Documentation of consultation with the child’s case worker, where appropriate;
and a follow letter with the family advising that they may contact the agency
should they have a change of mind related to refusing follow-up contact, may
aid the agency in documenting follow up efforts related to this contract
requirement.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
This incident related to Special Investigation 2019C0420025 initiated 4/10/19. The
complaint pertained to allegations that an employee used excessive force, grabbed a
resident by the shirt, pulled him into the bathroom, and scratched his face on
purpose. The agency received a violation under R400.4112(1)(a)(b) for Staff
qualifications, and R400.4158(2)(a) for Discipline.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on 5/15/19, which
indicated the employee involved in the incident was terminated. Additionally, that at a
staff meeting, all staff were advised on the importance of using CPI standards, with
emphasize on de-escalation; and ensuring employee’s do not take residents into
rooms with no cameras. The corrective action plan was completed.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to Special Investigation 2019C0420010 initiated 11/27/18. The
complaint pertained to allegations that an employee called a resident a derogatory
name, and pushed the resident, causing him to hit his head against a wall. The
agency received a violation under R400.4158(2)(a)and (c) for Discipline.
An acceptable corrective action plan was submitted by the agency on 1/28/19, which
included disciplinary action for the employee, and notation of a last chance
agreement that should the employee have further behavior disciplinary reports,
termination of the employee would occur. The corrective action plan was completed.
The employee in special investigation 2019C0420010 was then involved in another
special investigation 2019C0420025. She was terminated after she repeated behavior
like that in 2019420010.
The facility has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the facility’s 2018 Interim inspection where it
received six employee records violations, three violations related to resident files and
two contract violations. The agency was successful with its corrective action plan.
The one repeat violation related to the agency’s utilization of Interns and volunteers.
The second corrective action plans related to Special Investigation 2019C0420022.
The complaint alleged an employee left residents unattended during shower time and
one resident attempted to get into or got into another resident’s shower. The agency
received a violation under R400.4127(3) for staff-to-resident ratio.
7

The agency submitted an acceptable action plan on 4/18/19 which indicated the
employee involved in the incident received a written warning; and that shower
protocol and treatment standards were reviewed with all staff at two separate staff
meetings.
The agency appears to be incompliance with this corrective action plan, no additional
complaints have been received in this area.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
